name: AIS
description: May 2025. Data relating to internet use was available online. No personal info was exposed.

name: Nintendo
description: Apr 2020. Unauthorised access to thousands of Nintendo Switch accounts. Hackers were able to use saved payment details to make purchases.

name: Pakistani mobile operators
description: Apr 2020. Personal details stolen from Jazz and other mobile networks were put up for sale for $2.1m in bitcoin.

name: US Marshals Service
description: May 2020. Prisoners had sensitive personal data stolen in December 2019. They were notified five months later.

name: db8151dd
description: May 2020. Aggregated data from multiple websites was discovered in an open database. It included addresses, job titles, phone numbers and social media profiles. The breach was dubbed 'db8151dd'.

name: EasyJet
description: May 2020. The airline became aware of a hack in January, but didn't notify customers until April. Email addresses, travel details and credit card details were stolen.

name: Microsoft
description: Jan 2020. Customer support records spanning 14 years were left online without password protection.

name: Dutch Government
description: Mar 2020. Two hard drives with data from 6.9m registered organ donors went missing. They contained contact details, ID numbers & signatures.

name: Virgin Media
description: Mar 2020. A poorly-configured database left names, email addresses and phone numbers exposed for 10 months.

name: Boots Advantage Card
description: Mar 2020. Hackers accessed Advantage Card records, but no financial data was stolen. Payment using points was suspended.

name: Tesco Clubcard
description: Mar 2020. Details of accrued loyalty points were accessed, but financial details weren't exposed.

name: Marriott Hotels
description: Mar 2020. Guest records were accessed using the logins of two employees between mid-Jan and end of Feb.

name: Zoom
description: Apr 2020. Email addresses, passwords and personal meeting URLs were sold on the dark web. It led to a host of zoom-bombing pranks.

name: Israeli government
description: Feb 2020. Names, addresses, and ID card numbers of every Israeli voter were found on an insecure website belonging to Elector, a political communications app.

name: MGM Hotels
description: Feb 2020. Data stolen during an 2019 hack of an MGM server was published on a hacking forum.

name: Buchbinder Car Rentals
description: Jan 2020. Correspondence, invoices and contracts containing personal details were left exposed on an unsecured company server.

name: Wawa
description: Dec 2019. Card-stealing malware was installed, and remained undiscovered for nine months.

name: Desjardins Group
description: June 2019. An employee of the Canadian financial firm leaked customer information outside the organisation: names, addresses, birthdates, social insurance numbers & transaction habits.

name: US Customs and Border Protection
description: June 2019. Photos of faces and license plates taken at an US border crossing were stolen in a cyberattack on a surveillance contractor.

name: Quest Diagnostics
description: June 2019. For an 8 month period, a hacker group stole personal and payment information from a firm providing billing services for the US healthcare sector.

name: Australian National University
description: June 2019. A hacker accessed personal information including addresses, bank account details, payroll information and academic records. Staff, students and visitors were affected.

name: Canva
description: May 2019. Names, email addresses and location data belonging to users of an Australian graphic design service were stolen by a hacker.

name: First American Financial Corporation
description: May 2019. Anyone with a web browser could access these First American insurance documents dating back to 2003. Bank details, mortgage & tax records, social security numbers, drivers license images.

name: Chtrbox
description: May 2019. Contact details for millions of Instagram influencers, celebrities and brand accounts was left exposed in an online database for at least six days.

name: WiFi Finder
description: Apr 2019. An Android app for finding local WiFi passwords inadvertently provided access to the entire database, including domestic WiFi points.

name: Toyota
description: Apr 2019. A security breach of Toyota subsidiaries' IT systems may have leaked personal customer information.

name: Unknown
description: Mar 2019. A Dutch researcher found women's personal information in an open Chinese database. It included phone numbers, addressed and their "BreedReady" status, whatever that might be.

name: VÃ¥rdguiden
description: Feb 2019. 170,000 hours of sensitive calls to Sweden's healthcare hotline were stored on an open web server with no encryption or authentication. The breach was blamed on a subcontractor, Medicall.

name: Dubsmash
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: ShareThis
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: HauteLook
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: Animoto
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: EyeEm
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: 8fit
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: Whitepages
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: Fotolog
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: Armor Games
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: BookMate
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: CoffeeMeetsBagel
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: Artsy
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: DataCamp
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 617 million online account details from 16 hacked websites, put up for sale on the dark web.

name: Ixigo
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: YouNow
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: Houzz
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: Ge.tt
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: Coinmama
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: Roll20
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: Stronghold Kingdoms
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: Petflow
description: Feb 2019. Part of the theft of 127 million online account details from 8 hacked websites. They were put up for sale on the dark web 1 week after a similar tranche of 617 million records from 16 other websites.

name: 500px
description: Feb 2019. A July 2018 hack exposed the personal information of all 500px users, including names, usernames, email addresses, encrypted passwords, location, birth date, and gender.

name: Blur
description: Jan 2019. A server belonging to the password manager service contained a freely accessible file with users' email addresses, names and encrypted passwords.

name: Blank Media Games
description: Jan 2019. A hacker stole usernames, email addresses and encrypted passwords belonging to players of the game "Town of Salem" from an insecure server.

name: Indian citizens
description: May 2019. The discovery of a huge, unprotected MongoDB database containing personal information of Indian citizens, including their education, resume and current salary.

name: Bulgarian National Revenue Agency
description: Jul 2019. A hacker stole personal details of Bulgarian citizens from 110 government databases. 5m records, out of a total population of 7m.

name: Capital One
description: Jul 2019. The massive data breach included personal information from credit card applications over a 14-year period. A former Amazon employee, Paige Thompson, awaits trial for fraud.

name: Suprema
description: Aug 2019. A biometric security company stored unencrypted usernames and passwords, fingerprints and facial recognition information on a publicly accessible database.

name: Facebook
description: Sep 2019. Several unprotected databases were found to contain the phone numbers of around 20% of all Facebook users, with (in some cases) names and locations.

name: DoorDash
description: Sep 2019. Users who joined the platform before April 2018 had their names, email addresses, order history, phone numbers and encrypted passwords stolen in a hack.

name: BriansClub
description: Oct 2019. A site selling stolen payment card data was hacked and 26 million records were leaked. Banks were able to invalidate those cards, taking around 1/3 of the world's stolen cards out of circulation.

name: Microsoft
description: Microsoft's threat research team discovered 44 million users of Azure and Microsoft Services Accounts were using leaked credentials to log in.

name: People Data Labs
description: Nov 2019. Stashes of personal information originally compiled by a data aggregation firm were found on an insecure server. It included names, email addresses, phone numbers, LinkedIn and Facebook information.

name: OxyData
description: Nov 2019. Information compiled by a data aggregation firm were found on an insecure server. It included complete scrapes of LinkedIn data, including recruiter information.

name: Click2Gov
description: Dec 2018. Vulnerabilities in government payment software allowed hackers to access financial records and personal data across 46 US cities.

name: SingHealth
description: July 2018. Hackers stole personal details of 1.5 million patients, as well as the prescription details of 160,000 people, including prime minister Lee Hesien Loong.

name: GovPayNow.com
description: Sep 2018. A company used by US government agencies to accept online payments exposed personal records via a standard web browser, including addresses, phone numbers and credit card digits.

name: Cathay Pacific Airways
description: Oct 2018. Stolen data included names, nationalities, birth dates, phone numbers, addresses, passport & identity card numbers & expired credit card numbers.

name: Chinese resume leak
description: Dec 2018. Information thought to have been scraped from Chinese jobseeking websites was found in an insecure database. It included resumes, phone numbers, height, weight, driving license & literacy level.

name: WordPress
description: Aug 2018. According to security researchers, WordPress was notified of a security vulnerability over a year ago, but did not address it. No reports have been received which suggest the exploit is being actively used in the wild.

name: Google+
description: Dec 2018. A new vulnerability could have exposed users' personal details to developers, even if their profiles were set to private. Google will now shut down the consumer version of the social network 4 months earlier than planned.

name: Quora
description: Dec 2018. Compromised: logins for around 100m visitors who use the site to ask and answer questions about politics, faith, calculus, unrequited love, the meaning of life and more

name: Marriott Hotels
description: Nov 2018. Sensitive data on customer to all Starwood hotels (including Sheraton, Regis, W Hotels) leaked since 2014. Credit card details and some passport info. The size of the hack was downsized from 500 million to 383 million following an investigation.

name: NMBS
description: Dec 2018. Data stored on a non-secure server, making it possible to access names, gender, DOB, email and postal address data of customers externally by means of a simple search engine query. Most of the data belong to customers in Belgium, France and the UK, including thousands of Commission and Parliament employees.  Caused, the NMBS said, by a data worker âclicking on the wrong buttonâ.

name: Facebook
description: Mar 2018. Cambridge Analytica, headed at the time by Steve Bannon, harvested 50m profiles in early 2014 to build a system that could profile US voters and target them with political adverts.

name: Panerabread
description: Apr 2018. Customer records were available via the bakery chain's site for at least 8 months. Panerabread were alerted to the leak in Aug 2017, but didn't pull the site until Apr 2018. Panerabread claims 10k records were leaked, but security researchers put the figure at over 37 million.

name: Dixons Carphone
description: Jun 2018. Dixons Carphone revealed personal info for 10 million customers was stolen sometime in 2017.

name: MyHeritage
description: Jun 2018. Email addresses and encrypted passwords were stolen. As yet there is no evidence that the hackers have used the data.

name: Saks and Lord & Taylor
description: Apr 2018. A known ring of cybercriminals implanted software into store cash registers, siphoning off payment card details. The company has not divulged the full extent of the breach. Researchers estimate 5m records.

name: Careem
description: Apr 2018. Careem's official blog stated there was no evidence of payment info having been stolen, but it did admit that names, email address, phone numbers, and trip data were hacked.

name: Texas voter records
description: Aug 2018. A single file containing 14.8 million records was left on an unsecured server without a password. Data exposed included name, address, gender, and voting history.

name: British Airways
description: Sep 2018. Personal and financial details of customers making bookings between Aug 21st and Sep 5th were compromised.

name: T-Mobile
description: Aug 2018. T-Mobile initially said that personal data was stolen, but no passwords or financial info. They later admitted that encrypted passwords had been stolen.

name: MyFitnessPal
description: Mar 2018. Usernames, email addresses, and hashed user passwords were stolen.

name: Health South East
description: Feb 2018. Health data was stolen from more than half of Norway's population.

name: Nametests
description: Jun 2018. A security failure in a popular quiz app on Facebook left millions of peopleâs data exposed for almost two years. The data exposed included pictures, status updates, friends lists etc.

name: Ticketmaster
description: Jun 2018. Malicious software on third-party customer support product Inbenta Technologies caused the hack, and was likely to have affected UK customers who bought tickets between Feb and June 2018.

name: Firebase
description: Jun 2018. Thousands of iOS and Android mobile applications are exposing over 113 GBs of data via 2,271+ misconfigured Firebase databases.

name: Aadhaar
description: Mar 2018. A security researcher discovered a system vulnerability which means that anybody could download private info on all Aadhaar users. The govt. department that deals with the database has denied the breach.

name: Grindr
description: Mar 2018. A third-party tool that allows users to see who blocked them on Grindr was able to access non-public personal info, including exact locations of users who had opted out of location sharing.

name: Orbitz
description: Mar 2018. An old version of the travel website was hacked, exposing personal details and payment card info. Orbitz is now owned by Expedia.

name: MBM Company
description: Mar 2018. Negligent storage of a customer database exposed full postal addresses, email addresses, IP addresses and plain-text passwords.

name: LocalBlox
description: May 2018. A cloud storage repository was left publically accessible. Data included names, addresses, DOBs, social media info etc.

name: Twitter
description: May 2018. A glitch caused some passwords to be stored in readable text, visible on the internal computer system.

name: ViewFines
description: May 2018. Data published included names, ID numbers, cell numbers, email addresses and plain text passwords.

name: TicketFly
description: Aug 2018. Names, addresses, email addresses and phone numbers were stolen.

name: Amazon
description: Nov 2018. Customer names & email addresses were disclosed on its website. Amazon hasn't confirmed how many records were exposed.

name: Amazon
description: Nov 2018. Customer names and email addresses accidentally disclosed on its website, just two days ahead of Black Friday. No of users affected not released.

name: Urban Massage
description: Nov 2018. Database contained over 351,000 booking records, and more than 2,000 records on Urban massage therapists, including their names, email addresses and phone numbers.

name: Dell
description: Nov 2018. Dell detected & disrupted unauthorized activity on its network attempting to extract Dell customer information, which was included names, email addresses & hashed passwords

name: High Tail Hall
description: Nov 2018. Hackers were able to obtain email addresses, names, order histories, hashed passwords, & both physical and IP addresses for 411,000 High Tail Hall players.

name: SKY Brasil
description: Nov 2018. Poorly configured Elastisearch servers exposed customer details including payment methods.

name: Vision Direct
description: Nov 2018. User numbers not revealed. The attackers made away with personal information, passwords and CVV security codes.

name: Healthcare.gov
description: Oct 2018. "Sensitive" information on applicants for health insurance was hacked.

name: CMS
description: Nov 2018. CMS states that no protected health info, banking or tax details were breached, but personal info, insurance, income etc might have been exposed.

name: Facebook
description: Oct 2018. Malicious third-party scrapers collected profile information from many Facebook users.

name: Newegg
description: Sep 2018. Hackers injected 15 lines of card skimming code on the online retailer's payments page which remained for more than a month between Aug 14 and Sep 18. With over 45m monthly visitors, it's unclear how many customers were breached.

name: Mount Olympus
description: A former employee of Mount Olympus Mortgage stole client information and loan files and took them with him when he went to work at Guaranteed Rate. Mount Olympus was awarded $25m in damages.

name: Apollo
description: Data readily available online. Included info that looked to have been from LinkedIn profiles.

name: Disqus
description: Dec 2017. Hackers stole 17.5m email addresses in 2012. About a third of those accounts contained passwords, which were hashed using the dated SHA-1 algorithm

name: RootsWeb
description: Dec 2017. Ancestry.com's community-driven site RootsWeb was exposed after passwords, email addresses and usernames were leaked from the server.

name: Yahoo
description: Mar 2017. User accounts have been hacked using forged cookies to log in without a password over a 2 year period.

name: Uber
description: Nov 2017. Uber paid the hackers $100,000 to delete the stolen data. Chief security officer Joe Sullivan has resigned.

name: Wonga
description: Apr 2017. Customers from the UK and Poland look to have been affected.

name: Snapchat
description: Apr 2017. Indian hackers apparently leaked data they stole last year in response to Snapchat CEO allegedly stating they had no plans to expand to 'poor countries' like India. Snapchat have yet to confirm any leak.

name: Spambot
description: Aug 2017. A misconfigured spambot has leaked over 700m records, although many of them are likely to be fake or repeated accounts.

name: CEX
description: Aug 2017. A misconfigured spambot leaked full contact info & financial details, although the newest financial data dates to 2009.

name: Al.type
description: Dec 2017. The app's developer failed to secure the database server.

name: Cellebrite
description: Jan 2017. Cellebrite's main product is a device that rips data from mobile phones. 900GB of data was stolen from Cellebrite. The hackers got hacked. The number of records taken is unknown.

name: Waterly
description: Jan 2017. Israel-based app contained a vulnerability in the sign-in process that could potentially expose user account details. The problem was fixed within 2 weeks of being identifiied.

name: Swedish Transport Agency
description: Jul 2017. Information about all vehicles in the country (including military and police), made available to IT workers who hadn't been through usual security checks. The question of whether or not Sweden's national security was harmed is censored in the SÃ¤po (Sweden's security police) report.

name: Hong Kong Registration & Electoral Office
description: Mar 2017. "the personal information of the cityâs 3.7 million voters was possibly compromised after the Registration and Electoral Office reported two laptop computers went missing at its backup venue for the chief executive election."

name: River City Media
description: Mar 2017. A dodgy backup has allegedly resulted in over a billion leaked email addresses, plus other personal info in some cases, and has exposed RCM's business plans & operations.

name: DaFont
description: May 2017. Apparently the hacker found out others were selling the site's database, so he decided to get in on the action himself.

name: Bell
description: May 2017. Somebody claiming to be behind the attack has threatened Bell with more leaks if they don't cooporate.

name: Zomato
description: May 2017. The hacker is selling the stolen dataset for around $1000.

name: Imgur
description: Nov 2017. Imgur are still investigating how the breach took place. The data was stolen in 2014, but Imgur claim they only discovered it in Nov 2017.

name: TIO Networks
description: Dec 2017. The company has not revealed what type of information was stolen.

name: Malaysian telcos & MVNOs
description: Oct 2017. Data from numerous Malaysian telco & MVNO providers, including Celcom, Digi, Umobile, Maxis, Friendi, Merchantrade Asia, Tunetalk, Redtone, XOX, Altel, PLDT & EnablingAsia has been leaked.

name: Malaysian medical practitioners
description: Oct 2017. Databases belonging to the Malaysian Medical Council (MMC), the Malaysian Medical Association (MMA), and the Malaysian Dental Association (MDA) have been leaked. The data is from 2014.

name: Instagram
description: Sep 2017. A bug exposed user's contact information. Instagram initially said it affected only verified accounts, but has now admitted non-verified users were also affected. Instagram hasn't confirmed numbers, but hackers say they have info from 6m accounts.

name: Viacom
description: Sep 2017. A misconfigured Amazon Web Server S3 cloud storage bucket was left wide open and public facing.

name: Equifax
description: Sep 2017. If you have a credit report, thereâs a good chance that youâre one of the 143 million American consumers whose sensitive personal information was exposed in a data breach at Equifax, one of the nationâs three major credit reporting agencies.

name: SVR Tracking
description: Sep 2017. The leaked passwords were stored using SHA-1, a weak 20yr old hash program.

name: LinkedIn
description: May 2016. What initially seemed to be a theft of 6.5 million passwords has actually turned out to be a breach of 117 million passwords.

name: Tumblr
description: May 2016. Tumblr claimed it just found out about a 2013 data breach, which independent researchers claim affected 65m users.

name: Yahoo
description: Sep 2016. Happened in 2014, but no. records stolen was originally thought to be much smaller. Yahoo revealed the real numbers in 2016.

name: Mossack Fonseca
description: Apr 2016. 2.6TB of data on politicians, criminals, professional athletes etc leaked from law firm Mossack Fonseca, including emails, contracts, scanned documents, transcripts...

name: Philippinesâ Commission on Elections
description: Apr 2016. After a message was posted on the COMELEC website by hackers from Anonymous, warning the government not to mess with the elections, the entire database was stolen and posted online.

name: Syrian government
description: Apr 2016. Hacking outfit calling itself 'Cyber Justice Team' leaked 10GB of data from the government and private websites. Seems to be just data from old leaks, though.

name: Minecraft
description: Apr 2016. Players using the Lifeboat servers have had their email addresses and passwords leaked.

name: Turkish citizenship database
description: Apr 2016. Turkish citizenship database has allegedly been hacked and leaked online.

name: Banner Health
description: Aug 2016. Hackers gained access to payment card data via food outlets at Banner Health locations.

name: Mail. ru
description: Aug 2016. Two hackers attacked three game-related forums hosted by Russian company Mail.ru.

name: PayAsUGym
description: Dec 2016. Fitness website hacked & email address published online.

name: Lynda.com
description: Dec 2016. Hackers breached a database that held records of contact info and courses viewed. No official statement yet on how many records were actually stolen, and no evidence yet of them having been published anywhere.

name: Linux Ubuntu forums
description: Jul 2016. 2 million usernames, email addresses, and IP addresses associated with the Ubuntu Forums were taken by an unnamed attacker. The attacker was able to exploit an SQL injection vulnerability in an add-on used by older vBulletin forum software.

name: Wendy's
description: Jul 2016. Malware has been used in 1025 of Wendy's restaurants to steal credit card data from customers. It's currently unknown how many individuals have been impacted.

name: Clinton campaign
description: Jul 2016. The computer network used by Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton's campaign was hacked as part of a broad cyber attack on Democratic political organizations

name: uTorrent
description: Jun 2016. It's unclear what data has been breached, exactly, but uTorrent has advised passwords are probably compromised.

name: World Check
description: Jun 2016. 2014 version of World-Check, a database of suspected terrorists and criminals, leaked online. It's unclear what data the records include.

name: Mutuelle Generale de la Police
description: Jun 2016. Files uploaded to Google Drive by a 'malicious' employee. Data included home addresses. The leak came two weeks after a French police officer was murdered by ISIS-inspired attack.

name: VK
description: Jun 2016. Over 100m user accounts were hacked and the data put up for sale online. A VK spokesperson has denied that the site was breached, claiming the data for sale is old details no longer in use.

name: KM.ru & Nival
description: Mar 2016. A teen hacker has randomly hacked several Russian websites. In a statement, he claims the hack was revenge for the MH17 crash. The companies affected have not commented, however Troy Hunt, a security researcher, has confirmed its legit. Nival and KM.ru were both hacked.

name: Fling
description: May 2016. A hacker claims to be selling info on sexual desires & preferences, as well as generic personal info, stolen from the dating site Fling. The data is allegedly from 2011.

name: MySpace
description: May 2016. The same hacker who was selling LinkedIn user data now claims to have MySpace user data too, and lots of it.

name: Three
description: Nov 2016. Hackers broke into Three's customer database with the intention of fraudulently ordering handsets to sell on. They stole personal details, but no financial records or passwords were stored on the hacked system.

name: Red Cross Blood Service
description: Oct 2016. Info leaked includes data about 'at risk sexual behaviours'

name: Telegram
description: Aug 2016. Despite Telegram's claims of super security, they've been hacked by a group called Rocket Kitten.

name: Dailymotion
description: Dec 2016. 85.2m email addresses extracted, but only 18.3m had associated passwords.

name: Weebly
description: Oct 2016. Usernames, passwords and IP addresses stolen, although passwords secured with bcrypt.

name: Interpark
description: July 2016. South Korean police are blaming North Korea for stealing data in an attempt to obtain foreign currency.

name: Quest Diagnostics
description: Dec 2016. The stolen data contained names, DOBs, lab results and some telephone numbers.

name: Friend Finder Network
description: Nov 2016. Usernames, email addresses, passwords for sites including Adult Friend Finder and Penthouse.com. Passwords encrypted, but LeakedSource claims to be able to crack 99% of them.

name: Brazzers
description: Sep 2016. 'The data contains 790,724 unique email addresses, and also includes usernames and plaintext passwords. (The set has 928,072 entries in all, but many are duplicates.'

name: ClixSense
description: Sep 2016. The information stolen contains usernames, passwords, home addresses, payment histories, and other banking details.

name: Carefirst
description: May 2015. Evidence suggests the attackers could have potentially acquired member-created user names created by individuals to access CareFirstâs website, as well as membersâ names, birth dates, email addresses and subscriber identification number.

name: Twitch.tv
description: Mar 2015. Details unknown at this point. All Twitch's 10 million users have been requested to change their passwords.

name: Premera
description: Mar 2015. Hack occured May 2014. "could include names, date of birth, email address, address, telephone number, Social Security number, member identification numbers, bank account information, and claims information, including clinical information"

name: Uber
description: Feb 2015. Occured Sep 2014. Names & license plates of 50,000 driver partners.

name: Deep Root Analytics
description: Dec 2015. A database of 198 million US voters has been exposed as a result of incorrect configuration.

name: Kromtech
description: Dec 2015. A security researcher stumbled on a leak, which exposed usernames, email addresses and passwords of users. He notified Kromtech, who patched it quickly.

name: Invest Bank
description: Dec 2015. Hacker breached a United Arab Emirates bank, demanding a ransom of $3m in bitcoin to stop tweeting data, mostly about corporate accounts. The hacker dumped files on the website of a basketball team, which he hacked for storage. The bank, Invest Bank, won't pay the ransom.

name: Sanrio
description: Dec 2015. Security researcher was able to access a database of 3.3m of Sanrio's Sanriotown.com accounts, with links to other Sanrio Hello Kitty portals.

name: VTech
description: Dec 2015. Software used to download games to children's computer tablets was hacked, with personal info and photos stolen.

name: Hacking Team
description: Jul 2015. Italian cybersecurity firm sells digital surveillance software to law enforcement and national security organisations. 400 GB of documents - including software source code, private messages & client databases - has been stolen and put online  via BitTorrent. The documents show the company has sold products to repressive regimes.

name: AshleyMadison.com
description: Jul 2015. Online hookup site for extra-marital affairs has been severely breached and the personal details of 37m users, as well as company financial records, threatened with release. Notorious hacking outfit The Impact Team has claimed responsibility. The hackers demanded the shutdown of AM.com and other associated sites.

name: US Office of Personnel Management (2nd Breach)
description: Jul 2015. Attackers have targeted the forms submitted by intelligence and military personnel for security clearances. The document includes personal information - everything from eye colour, to financial history, to past substance abuse, as well as contact details for the individual's friends and relatives

name: US Office of Personnel Management
description: Jun 2015. "The intruders... gained access to...employeesâ Social Security numbers, job assignments, performance ratings and training information"

name: Australian Immigration Department
description: Mar 2015. An employee of the agency inadvertently sent the passport numbers, visa details and other personal identifiers of all world leaders attending the G20 Brisbane summit to the organisers of the Asian Cup football tournament. Barack Obama, Vladimir Putin, Angela Merkel, Xi Jinping, Narendra Modi, David Cameron and many others.

name: IRS
description: May 2015. "An unnamed cybermafia used an IRS app to download forms full of personal information. They posed as legitimate taxpayers, and tried to download forms on 200,000 people between February and May. They got away with half of them, the IRS said. The crooks used about 15,000 of them to claim tax refunds in other people's names."

name: MSpy
description: May 2015. Data dump to the dark web "includes Apple IDs and passwords, tracking data, and payment details on some 145,000 successful transactions", photos and very private conversations.

name: Adult Friend Finder
description: May 2015. Sexual preferences, names, email addresses, usernames, dates of birth, postal codes.

name: Securus Technologies
description: Nov 2015. Anonymous hacker leaked records of over 70m phone calls, plus links to recordings. Recording/storing attorney-client calls potentially violates constitutional protections.

name: TalkTalk
description: Nov 2015. 157k customers had personal details stolen, including 15,600 account numbers.

name: Experian / T-mobile
description: Oct 2015. The world's biggest data monitoring firm disclosed a massive breach of customers who applied for service with T-Mobile. Names, addresses, birth dates, Social Security numbers, drivers license numbers and passport numbers.

name: Slack
description: Mar 2015. Sometime in February, hackers were able to peruse Slackâs central database for up to four days.

name: CarPhone Warehouse
description: Aug 2015. Around 480,000 of the 2.4 million customers affected by the breach are TalkTalk Mobile customers and 1.9m were customers of Carphone Warehouse directly.

name: British Airways
description: Mar 2015. Hackers have accessed tens of thousands of British Airways frequent-flyer accounts. The airline said no personal information had been viewed or stolen and it had frozen affected accounts while it resolves the issue.

name: Anthem
description: Feb 2015. Names, dates of birth, member ID/ social security numbers, addresses, phone numbers, email addresses and employment information.

name: UCLA Health
description: May 2015. Officials said the cyberattack was confirmed to have impacted those systems with patient information, including names, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, Medicaid or health plan identification numbers, and some medical data. In 2019, UCLA Health reached a $2million class-action lawsuit settlement with the 4.5 million current and former patients.

name: Neiman Marcus
description: Jan 2014. Malware had been âclandestinelyâ put into the Neiman Marcus system & had stolen payment data off cards used from July 16 to Oct. 30

name: AOL
description: Apr 2014. Users' accounts were compromised to send out spam messages.

name: Community Health Systems
description: Aug 2014. Community Health Systems, which operates 206 hospitals across the US, had patient data from the last 5 years breached. Details included names, addresses, social security numbers. Suspected "chinese hackers" were thought responsible. Goal: identity theft.

name: Privatization Agency of the Republic of Serbia
description: Dec 2014. A text file with personal data and financial documents were made publically available on their website.

name: Sony Pictures
description: Dec 2014. Wide-ranging hack of potentially every piece of data held by the company, including: unreleased films & scripts, employee social security numbers, salaries and health check results, as well as sensitive internal business documents relating to lay-offs, restructures and executive salaries. Lead suspects are "North Korean hackers" perhaps related to the Seth Rogen film, "The Interview" which mocks the North Korean dictator, Kim Jong Un.

name: Indiana University
description: Feb 2014. Students who attended the university between 2011 and 2014 may have had their data exposed after it was stored on an unprotected site. The data was accessed by three webcrawlers but there is not evidence it was accessed by any unauthorized individuals.

name: Ebay
description: May 2014. The company has said hackers attacked between late February and early March with login credentials obtained from âa small numberâ of employees. They then accessed a database containing all user records and copied âa large partâ of those credentials.

name: UPS
description: Aug 2014. Malware was discovered in the credit & debit card processing systems at 51 branches in 24 states.

name: European Central Bank
description: Jul 2014. The ECB received an anonymous call requesting money in return for the stolen data. The bank didn't say how much the blackmailer asked for, but did say that it refused to pay anything.

name: JP Morgan Chase
description: Oct 2014. The US's largest bank was compromised by hackers, stealing names, addresses, phone numbers and emails of account holders. The hack began in June but was not discovered until July, when the hackers had already obtained the highest level of administrative privilege to dozens of the bankâs computer servers.

name: New York Taxis
description: Jun 2014. A freedom of information request resulted in the release of data on all 173 million journeys undertaken by New York taxis in one year. Unfortunately, the data was incorrectly anonymised and relatively easy to decode, revealing the driver IDs, pickup & dropoff times, and GPS routes taken for every single cab journey.

name: HSBC Turkey
description: Nov 2014. "In a message to customers on its website, the bank said an attack on its credit card and debit card systems in Turkey had been thwarted but card numbers, account numbers, card expiry dates and customer names had been âcompromisedâ."

name: Japan Airlines
description: Sep 2014. Japan Airlines confirmed the possible theft of information from up to around 750,000 frequent-flier programme members. Data that may have been stolen included names, genders, birth dates, addresses, email addresses and places of work.

name: Staples
description: Dec 2014. Staples believes that point-of-sale systems at 115 Staples locations were infected with malware that thieves may have used to steal customersâ names, payment card numbers, expiration dates and card verification codes

name: "Gmail"
description: Sep 2014. 5 million Gmail account passwords leaked to a forum, alongside passwords from other email providers. Close inspection revealed the user details to be old (3+ years). Multiple individual targeted hacks of third party websites where people used their Gmail IDs, rather than one big dataleak, suspected to be the method. Gmail itself was not hacked.

name: Home Depot
description: Sep 2014. Malware installed on cash register system across 2,200 stores syphoned credit card details of up to 56 million customers. May be the same group of Russian and Ukrainian hackers responsible for the data breaches at Target, Sally Beauty and P.F. Changâs, among others

name: Korea Credit Bureau
description: Jan 2014. An employee from personal credit ratings firm Korea Credit Bureau (KCB) has been arrested and accused of stealing the data from customers of three credit card firms while working for them as a temporary consultant.

name: Dominios Pizzas (France)
description: Jun 2014. Hackers have demanded a ransom of â¬30,000 (Â£24,000) from Domino's Pizza after stealing personal data on more than 600,000 of its French and Belgian customers.

name: Mozilla
description: Aug 2014. Members of Mozillaâs developer community have been alerted about an accidental leak of email addresses and encrypted passwords, after the failure of a âdata sanitisationâ process the organisation was carrying out.

name: Massive American business hack
description: Jul 2013. From 2005 to 2012, a hacking ring targeted banks, payment processors and chain stores, to steal more than 160 million credit and debit card numbers, targeting more than 800,000 bank accounts

name: Affinity Health Plan, Inc.
description: Aug 2013. A rented photocopier used to copy health records did not have its hard-drive wiped before its return.

name: Citigroup
description: Jul 2013. Third big data breach from Citigroup."The personal information of 150,000 consumers who went into bankruptcy between 2007 and 2011 â including their social security numbers â were exposed after Citi failed to properly redact court records before they were put on the Public Access to Court Electronic Records (PACER) system."

name: Tianya
description: Jul 2013. China's biggest online forum confirmed that private information for 40 million users had been leaked

name: Scribd
description: Apr 2013. Hack resulted in a few hundred thousand stolen passwords (figure is approximate)

name: Kissinger Cables
description: Apr 2013. More than 1.7 million US diplomatic records for the period 1973 to 1976, including intelligence reports and congressional correspondence.

name: Living Social
description: Apr 2013. Online criminals gained access to user names, e-mail addresses, dates of birth & encrypted passwords for 50 million people. Databases storing financial information were not compromised in the attack, the company said.

name: Yahoo
description: Dec 2016. Happened in 2013 but only disclosed late 2016. Data included names, telephone numbers, DOBs, passwords and security questions.

name: SnapChat
description: Jan 2014. Hackers abused an exploit to syphon 4.7m user details, including phone numbers.

name: University of Delaware
description: Aug 2013. Confidential personal information on past and current employees of the University of Delaware was stolen in an attack on a vulnerability in software acquired by a vendor.

name: Central Hudson Gas & Electric
description: Feb 2013. Customer banking information and other personal information may have been accessed during the hack.

name: Twitter
description: Feb 2013. Hackers had access to limited user information -- usernames, email addresses, session tokens and encrypted/salted versions of passwords -- for approximately 250,000 users.

name: Crescent Health Inc., Walgreens
description: Feb 2013. Names, Social Security numbers, health insurance identification numbers, health insurance information, dates of birth, diagnoses, other medical information, disability codes, addresses, and phone numbers may have been exposed via a laptop theft.

name: Florida Department of Juvenile Justice
description: Jan 2013. Memorial Healthcare System, Hollywood, Fla., is notifying nearly 9,500 patients of an investigation into two former employees who inappropriately accessed patient information. The workers, whose employment was terminated, may have sought to process false tax returns using the information.

name: Advocate Medical Group
description: Aug 2013. 4,000,000 patient names, addresses, dates of birth, and Social Security numbers were contained in four computers stolen from an administrative building. Second biggest security breach ever reported to the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS).

name: OVH
description: Jul 2013. A hacker was able to obtain access to an email account of a system administrator, then to the internal VPN of another employee, with which they were able to compromise the access of one of the system administrators who handles the the internal backoffice.

name: Apple
description: Jul 2013. Developer portal hacked. "Some" information about 275,000 3rd-party developers potentially stolen.

name: NASDAQ
description: Jul 2013. Nasdaq forum website hacked by hacking ring, email addresses and passwords compromised

name: UbiSoft
description: Jul 2013. The video games publisher said that user names, email addresses and encrypted passwords had been "illegally accessed", but that subscribers' debit and credit card details remained safe as it did not store them.

name: Ubuntu
description: July 2013. Discussion forum for the operating system was compromised leaking personal details and password. The passwords were cryptographically scrambled using the MD5 hashing algorithm - considered an inadequate means of protecting stored passwords by security experts.

name: Nintendo
description: Jun 2013. Japan's Club Nintendo service was hacked following thousands of unauthorized accesses. Customer information compromised in the attack includes full names, phone numbers, home and email addresses.

name: National Security Agency
description: Jun 2013. Snowden downloaded up to 1.5 million files, then flew to Hong Kong to meet journalists Glenn Greenwald and Laura Poitras before fleeing to Moscow.

name: Facebook
description: Jun 2013. Using the network's "Download Your Information" tool, some Facebook members were inadvertently sent the phone numbers or email address of Facebook friends that were otherwise private. Facebook assured users that the bug was fixed within a day, and that there is no evidence that the information was used maliciously.

name: Evernote
description: Mar 2013. Evernote asked its 50 million users to reset their passwords following an attempt to hack the note-taking network. The company said itâd found no evidence that any payment information for Evernote Premium or Evernote Business customers had been accessed, nor was there any indication that content stored by users had been accessed, changed or lost.

name: Kirkwood Community College
description: Apr 2013. Hackers accessed application information from February 2006 to March 13, 2013, including applicant names, birthdates, race, contact information and Social Security numbers.

name: Yahoo Japan
description: May 2013. 22 million Yahoo user IDs may have been leaked after Yahoo detected an unauthorized attempt to access the administrative system of its web portal Yahoo Japan. The leaked information did not include passwords and data necessary for identity verification to reset passwords.

name: Drupal
description: May 2013. Malicious files placed on association.drupal.org servers via a 3rd-party application. Exposed usernames, e-mail addresses, country information, and cryptographically hashed passwords.

name: TerraCom & YourTel
description: May 2013. The telecom firms TerraCom and YourTel have branded reporters for Scripps News as "hackers" after journalists discovered that the personal data of over 170,000 customers - including social security numbers and other identifying data that could be used for identity theft - were sitting on a publicly accessible server.

name: Washington State court system
description: May 2013. Up to 160,000 Social Security numbers and a million driver's license numbers may have been accessed by hackers exploiting old versions of Adobe Cold Fusion software on the server.

name: MacRumours.com
description: Nov 2013. The MacRumors intrusion involved "a moderator account being logged into by the hacker who then was able to escalate their privileges with the goals of stealing user login credentials

name: Court Ventures
description: Oct 2013. A lawsuit against the Vietnamese identity theft service contends that the theft of up to 3 million records began in 2010 and was orchestrated by a then-teenager in Vietnam, Hieu Minh Ngo. Ngo, posing as private investigator based in Singapore, gained access to a database of consumer information. He has since been sentenced to 13 years in prison.

name: Vodafone
description: Sep 2013. An IT contractor for the firm used his deep access to the telecom giant's system to copy customer names and bank account details.

name: Adobe
description: Oct 2013. Hackers obtained access to a large swathe of Adobe customer IDs and encrypted passwords & removed sensitive information (i.e. names, encrypted credit or debit card numbers, expiration dates, etc.). Approximately 36m customers: 3.1m stolen credit cards, 33m stolen encrypted passwords. Correction Jan 2015: we previously reported 152m records taken, but the remainder affected invalid, inactive, test accounts or had out-of-date passwords associated with them.

name: D&B, Altegrity
description: Sep 2013. Hackers stole millions of social security numbers from large US data brokers Dun & Bradstreet Corp and Kroll Background America Inc, owned by Altegrity. Correction 7 Jan 2015: we previously stated that records were stolen from LexisNexis. LexisNexis conducted a thorough investigation of the malware intrusion and found no evidence that the malware accessed or stole any customer or consumer data.

name: ssndob.ms
description: Sep 2013. SSNDOB was an underground identity theft service. Teenage hackers used it to collect data for exposed.su, a site that listed the SSNs, birthdays, phone numbers, current and previous addresses for dozens of top celebrities including Beyonce, Kanye West and Michelle Obama. In doing so they revealed SSNDOB had data on more than 4 million people.

name: Target
description: Dec 2013. Investigators believe the data was obtained via software installed on machines that customers use to swipe magnetic strips on their cards when paying for merchandise at Target stores. Originally 40m customers. Now 70m!

name: China Software Developer Network
description: Mar 2012. Police have arrested a man, surnamed Zeng, suspected of leaking personal information belonging to more than 6 million users of the China Software Developer Network (CSDN). Zeng has been detained on charges of illegal acquisition of computer data.

name: Global Payments
description: Apr 2012. 1.5 million credit card numbers from its systems may have been exposed after detecting âunauthorized accessâ into its processing system.

name: South Carolina Government
description: Apr 2012. A man was charged with five counts of violating medical confidentiality laws and one count of disclosure of confidential information after he gained access to personal information for more than 228,000 Medicaid beneficiaries.

name: Three Iranian banks
description: Apr 2012. After finding a security vulnerability in Iran's banking system, software manager Khosrow Zarefarid wrote a formal report and sent it to the CEOs of all the affected banks across the country. When the banks ignored his findings, he hacked 3 million bank accounts, belonging to at least 22 different banks, to prove his point.

name: California Department of Child Support Services
description: Apr 2012. California child support records were lost in transit during a disaster preparedness exercise.

name: Emory Healthcare
description: Apr 2012. The company 'misplaced' 10 discs containing sensitive information, including social security numbers.

name: Office of the Texas Attorney General
description: Apr 2012. The office of Texas Attorney General Greg Abbott mistakenly gave attorneys access to millions of Social Security numbers in a case against the stateâs voter ID law

name: Medicaid
description: Apr 2012. The Utah Department of Technology Services had recently moved their claims records to a new server, and hackers believed to be operating out of Eastern Europe were able to circumvent the serverâs multi-layered security system containing Social Security numbers for the Medicaid claims.

name: Blizzard
description: Aug 2012. Scrambled passwords, e-mail addresses, and personal security answers were knowingly stolen from Blizzard's internal network. Blizzard would not elaborate on the size of the hack ("millions").

name: New York State Electric & Gas
description: Jan 2012. An employee from a software consulting firm was allowed unauthorized access to the companyâs databases.

name: Memorial Healthcare System
description: Apr 2012. An employee of an affiliated physicianâs office may have improperly accessed patient information through a web portal used by physicians who provide care and treatment at MHS. Specifically, patientsâ names, dates of birth, and Social Security numbers.

name: Zappos
description: Jan 2012. The Amazon-owned e-commerce firm has revealed that it was the target of a cyber attack that gained access to its internal network.

name: Formspring
description: Jul 2012. Formspring was tipped off to a breach after 420,000 hashed passwords were posted to a security forum.

name: KT Corp.
description: Jul 2012. Two suspects reportedly earnt an estimated $877,000 by selling the contact information and plan details of 8.7 million KT subscribers, almost half of the carrier's total customers.

name: Yahoo Voices
description: Jul 2012. Yahoo Voices service was hacked, exposing more than 450,000 usernames and passwords.

name: Last.fm
description: Sep 2016. Usernames, email addresses, join date, and other internal records, such as newsletter sign-ups and ad-related data, were stolen in the 2012 breach

name: LinkedIn, eHarmony, Last.fm
description: Jun 2012. Hacker 'dwdm' uploaded a file containing 6.5 million passwords on a Russian hacker forum. Soon after another 1.5 million passwords were discovered.  On analysis, 93% of the passwords could be found in the Top 10,000 password list.

name: Gamigo
description: Jul 2012. 4 months after the gaming site Gamigo warned users about a hacker intrusion that accessed some portions of its users' credentials, more than 8 million usernames, emails & encrypted passwords from the site have been published on the web

name: Militarysingles.com
description: Mar 2012. Collective group LulzSec released a database of 163,792 names, usernames, e-mail addresses, IP addresses, and passwords of "single" military personnel.

name: "Apple"
description: Mar 2012. Hacking group AntiSec claimed they hacked an FBI laptop in March 2012 accessing a file of more than 12 million Apple Unique Device Identifiers (UDIDs). Subsequently, it was discovered that app developer BlueToad was the source of the breach. The list contained personal information such as full names, phone numbers and addresses. AntiSec published a million of these UDIDs online.

name: Greek government
description: Nov 2012. A computer programmer was arrested in Greece for allegedly stealing the identity information of what could amount to 83% of the country's population. The 35-year-old was found in possession of 9 million data files containing identification card data, addresses, tax ID numbers and licence plate numbers, which he was also suspected of trying to sell.

name: South Carolina State Dept. of Revenue
description: Oct 2012. A server was breached by an international hacker.

name: Dropbox
description: Aug 2016. User credentials were stolen in a 2012 hack, but the number affected has only just come to light.

name: New York City Health & Hospitals Corp.
description: Feb 2011. Computer backup tapes from the New York provider were stolen on Dec. 23, 2010, from a truck that was transporting them to a secure storage location.

name: Seacoast Radiology, PA
description: Jan 2011. Computer gamers hacked a server at Seacoast Radiology in Rochester in search of more bandwidth in November to play Call of Duty: Black Ops. In the process they also gained access to personal records of the more than 230,000 patients of the health center.

name: South Shore Hospital, Massachusetts
description: Sep 2011. South Shore Hospital hired a contractor to destroy files no longer in use and lost the shipment. The back-up computer files possibly contained names, addresses, phone numbers, dates of birth, Social Security numbers, driverâs license numbers, medical record numbers, patient numbers, health plan information, protected health information including diagnoses and treatments. As well as bank account and credit card numbers for some. Patients, employees, physicians, volunteers, donors, vendors and other business partners were effected.

name: Betfair
description: May 2011. Betfair waited 18 months to report the breach of their online gambling site, alarming banking institutions and security experts. Betfair's systems breach, which occurred in March and April 2010, was not uncovered until this past May, when a server crashed.

name: Ankle & foot Center of Tampa Bay, Inc.
description: Jan 2011. The information hacked included information such as patient names, social security numbers, date of birth, home addressees, account numbers, and healthcare services and related diagnostic codes.

name: Yale University
description: Aug 2011. The names and Social Security numbers of 43,000 people affiliated with the university were publicly viewable on Google for 10 months.

name: Morgan Stanley Smith Barney
description: Jul 2011. Morgan Stanley mailed a CD containing sensitive data about investors in tax-exempt funds and bonds to the New York State Department of Taxation and Finance. The package arrived at the building but when it arrived at the relevant desk the data CD was missing.

name: State of Texas
description: Apr 2011. 3.5 million records were accidentally published online including people's names, mailing addresses, social security numbers, and in some cases dates of birth and driver's license numbers.

name: Epsilon
description: Apr 2011. Names & email addresses of customers of Barclaycard US, Capital One, JP Morgan, Citigroup & other firms have been stolen.

name: Sony PSN
description: Apr 2011. Rounding off a thoroughly unhappy year for Sony, their third breach saw the loss of 76,000,000 Sony PSN and Qriocity user accounts to hacking collective Lulzsec.

name: US Law Enforcement
description: Aug 2011. "AntiSec" hackers published 2,719 social security numbers, 8,214 passwords, 15,798 birth dates, 48,182 street addresses, 1,531,628 email addresses, 106,691 phone numbers, 57 bank account numbers, 53 driver's license numbers, and eight credit card numbers of more than 70 different U.S. law enforcement agencies.

name: University of Wisconsin - Milwaukee
description: Aug 2011. The campus has been subject to a malware attack, which has exposed names and social security numbers of students -- past and present -- and staff alike.

name: Stratfor
description: Dec 2011. Hacking collective Anonymous defaced the website of Stratfor and posted online what they claimed was Stratfor's confidential client list, along with credit card details, passwords and home addresses for those clients. They released 47,680 unique e-mail addresses and 50,277 unique credit card numbers â 9,651 of which were not yet expired. Of the stolen encrypted passwords, 50% were easily crackable. Stratfor has stated that it was not the firm's client list that was released, but rather Stratfor's list of individual subscribers to their online publication.

name: Chinese gaming sites
description: Dec 2011. Several major Chinese gaming sites were hacked, breaching a total of 38,000,000 user records.

name: Southern California Medical-Legal Consultants
description: Jun 2011. Electronic files containing names and social security numbers of approximately 300,000 individuals who have applied for California workersâ compensation benefits had been exposed to unauthorized access.

name: Writerspace.com
description: Jun 2011. Hacker group LulzSec released the e-mails and passwords, 12,000 of which were confirmed to originate from Writerspace.com.

name: Bethesda Game Studios
description: Jun 2011. Hacking collective Lulzsec stole account information of 200,000 users.

name: Sega
description: Jun 2011. Information stolen during the hack includes names, birth dates, e-mail addresses and passwords from Sega Pass, a system for users interested in newsletters and for registering certain products.

name: Citigroup
description: Jun 2011. Less than 1% of Citbank card holders' names, account numbers, and contact information such as e-mail addresses were stolen. Card security codes were not stolen.

name: Sony Pictures
description: Jun 2011. LulzSec hacking collective stated all of the information it took was unencrypted, âSony stored over 1,000,000 passwords of its customers in plaintext." More than 1 million user accounts were compromised. An additional 75,000 music codes and 3.5 million coupons were also uncovered.

name: Accendo Insurance Co.
description: Jun 2011. Mismailed letters which allowed some lines of sensitive information (medication name, date of birth, and member ID) to be visible through the envelope window. The mailings were addressed correctly and, to the knowledge of the company, were received by the intended recipients.

name: Washington Post
description: Jul 2011. Unknown hackers broke into The Washington Post's jobs website stealing about 1.27 million user IDs and email addresses.

name: Health Net - IBM
description: Mar 2011. Several server drives, containing personal information of former and current employees, went missing.

name: Eisenhower Medical Center
description: Apr 2011. Stolen computer contained data listing patients' names, ages, dates of birth, medical record numbers and the last four digits of their social security numbers.

name: Spartanburg Regional Healthcare System
description: May 2011. The stolen computer contained a password-protected file with Social Security numbers as well as names, addresses, dates of birth and medical billing codes.

name: NHS
description: Jun 2011. A laptop holding the unencrypted records of eight million patients went missing from an NHS store room and wasn't reported until 3 weeks later.

name: San Francisco Public Utilities Commission
description: Jun 2011. An unsecured server that was storing customer data also had some viruses on it. It's unclear how the server got infected

name: Sony Online Entertainment
description: May 2011. Hacked by LulzSec. In addition to the Sony Playstation Network breach, compromised 77 million records. More than 23,000 lost financial data, according to Sony.

name: Honda Canada
description: May 2011. Names, addresses and vehicle identification numbers were taken from the companyâs eCommerce websites myHonda and myAcura

name: Massachusetts Government
description: May 2011. Over 1,500 departmental computers were infected with the W32.QAKBOT virus, a malicious program which âdownloads additional files, steals information, and opens a back door on the compromised computerâ.

name: Oregon Department of Motor Vehicles
description: May 2011. Sheriff's detectives arrested Tim Nuss for accessing an old Oregon Department of Motor Vehicles database. The DMV database was once sold to marketing companies, but the department stopped selling the information in the late 1990s. The sold data include the names, addresses, birth dates, gender and ages of people who registered with the DMV, but no financial information.

name: Steam
description: Nov 2011. Attackers used login details from a Steam forum hack to access a database that held ID and credit card data.

name: Restaurant Depot
description: Nov 2011. Cybercrooks presumed to be operating from Russia hacked into the Restaurant Depot database last month and accessed the credit and debit card details of more than 100,000 customers.

name: Nexon Korea Corp
description: Nov 2011. Personal data of subscribers to online game Maple Story was leaked.

name: Nemours Foundation
description: Oct 2011. A health care organization that runs childrenâs hospitals reported the loss of 1.05 million records when data backup tapes were lost.

name: Sutter Medical Foundation
description: Nov 2011. A password protected but unencrypted company computer was stolen. The compromised database contained names, addresses, dates of birth, phone numbers, email addresses, medical record numbers and the name of each patient's health insurance plan. No medical records were stored on the computer.

name: Tricare
description: Sep 2011. The information for some 4.6 million active and retired military personnel, as well as their families, was on back up-tapes from an electronic health care record used to capture and preserve patient data from 1992 through September 7 2011.

name: AvMed, Inc.
description: Feb 2010. Two company laptops containing names, addresses, dates of birth, Social Security numbers and health-related information.

name: Blue Cross Blue Shield of Tennessee
description: May 2010. A thief stole 57 hard drives from the closet of a BlueCross call center in Chattanooga, Tenn. Data on the stolen hard drives was encoded but not encrypted. Bluecross stated there was no evidence the information was accessed due to the specialized nature of the hardware stolen.

name: US Military
description: Nov 2010. "Hillary Clinton and several thousand diplomats around the world are going to have a heart attack when they wake up one morning and find an entire repository of classified foreign policy is available, in searchable format, to the public ... Everywhere there's a US post, there's a diplomatic scandal that will be revealed ... It's beautiful, and horrifying" - So wrote Bradley Manning, the 22-year-old former intelligence analyst, suspected of being behind the leak of more than 250,000 dispatches from US embassies around the world.

name: Gawker.com
description: Dec 2010. Hacked. 1.5 Million usernames, emails, passwords taken.

name: Triple-S Salud, Inc.
description: Nov 2010. One or more employees of Medical Card System (illegally) accessed restricted areas of their website.

name: Ohio State University
description: Dec 2010. The university cannot disclose how hackers accessed the server for security reasons and because the incident is still under investigation.

name: Emergency Healthcare Physicians, Ltd.
description: May 2010. The stolen portable hard drive is believed to have contained records from 2003 to 2006 that included patient names, addressees, phone numbers, birth dates, Social Security numbers, and, in some cases, drivers' license numbers.

name: Colorado government
description: Jul 2010. State officials discovered that there was an unauthorized removal of a computer hard drive housed at the Office of Information Technology (OIT)

name: AT&T
description: Jun 2010. Details of iPad 3G users hacked from AT&T website, thought to include those of White House chief of staff Rahm Emanuel.

name: Lincoln Medical & Mental Health Center
description: Jun 2010. 130,495 patients lost their protected health information after seven CDs were lost in transit.

name: Educational Credit Management Corp
description: Mar 2010. A contractor for the US Department of Education stole the records of 3.3 million people. Data included names, addresses, Social Security numbers and dates of birth of borrowers, but no financial or bank account information.

name: Embassy Cables
description: Nov 2010. "Hillary Clinton and several thousand diplomats around the world are going to have a heart attack when they wake up one morning and find an entire repository of classified foreign policy is available, in searchable format, to the public ... Everywhere there's a US post, there's a diplomatic scandal that will be revealed ... It's beautiful, and horrifying" - So wrote Bradley Manning, the 22-year-old former intelligence analyst, suspected of being behind the leak of more than 250,000 dispatches from US embassies around the world.

name: US Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland
description: Nov 2010. A Malaysian man has been charged with hacking into major U.S. corporations, including the U.S. Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland and FedComp after U.S. Secret Service investigators found more than "400,000 stolen credit and debit card account numbers allegedly obtained by hacking into various computer systems of other financial institutions"

name: Classified Iraq War documents
description: Oct 2010. In the biggest document dump in Wikileaks' short history and possibly the biggest breach of classified data ever, the whistle-blower organization has posted 391,832 classified Iraq War documents on its website.

name: Puerto Rico Department of Health
description: Sep 2010. Double whammy. Two separate breaches. On September 3rd, 2010 data on 115,000 people was stolen from unauthorized access of an electronic device, on the 21st they reported an additional 400,000 records were hacked.

name: Heartland
description: Jan 2009. The biggest credit card scam in history, Heartland eventually paid more than $110 million to Visa, MasterCard, American Express and other card associations to settle claims related to the breach. A hacker was sentenced to 20 years in prison for his role in this & other cases.

name: US National Guard
description: Dec 2009. About 131,000 former and current Army Guard members potentially affected  when a personal laptop owned by an Army Guard contractor was stolen. Database incuded names, Social Security Numbers, incentive payment amounts and payment dates.

name: RockYou!
description: Dec 2009. The site did not allow users to use special characters or punctuation in their passwords and e-mailed user passwords in plain text. Hackers took advantage of these security lapses, using simple techniques to gain access to 32 million user accounts.

name: CheckFree Corporation
description: Jan 2009. Customers who went to CheckFree's Web sites between 12:35 a.m. and 10:10 a.m. on the day of the attack were redirected to a Ukrainian Web server that used malicious software to try and install a password-stealing program on the victim's computer.

name: Network Solutions
description: Jul 2009. A large-scale infection of WordPress-driven blogs with malicious code led to the compromise of 573,000 debit and credit cards.

name: Virginia Prescription Monitoring Program
description: May 2009. A hacker, who was never arrested, demanded a $10 million ransom for a breach effecting 530,000 Virginians. Social security numbers may have been taken. The data was found in a database containing 35 million prescription records.

name: Virginia Dept. Of Health
description: May 2009. An extortion demand posted on WikiLeaks sought $10 million to return over 8 million patient records and 35 million prescriptions allegedly stolen from Virginia Department of Health Professions.  All 36 servers were shut down  to protect records.

name: University of California Berkeley
description: May 2009. The attackers accessed a public Web site and then bypassed additional secured databases stored on the same server. In addition to SSNs, the databases contained health insurance information and non-treatment medical information.

name: Health Net
description: Nov 2009. A portable hard drive with seven years of personal and medical information on about 1.5 million Health Net customers was lost for six months before being reported.

name: US Military
description: Oct 2009. Without first destroying the data the agency sent back a defective unencrypted hard drive for repair and recycling which held detailed records on 76 million veterans, including millions of Social Security numbers dating to 1972.

name: Compass Bank
description: Mar 2008. A former employee stole a hardrive containing 1m account details from the bank between May & July 2007, then used it to defraud cutomers of nearly $32,000.

name: Hannaford Brothers Supermarket Chain
description: Mar 2008. An estimated 4.2 million credit and debit card numbers were stolen.

name: University of Miami
description: Apr 2008. Thieves stole a briefcase containing data tapes out of a vehicle used by a private off-site storage company. Anyone who had been a patient of a University of Miami physician or visited a UM facility since 1999 is likely included on the tapes. The data included names, addresses, Social Security numbers and health information. 47,000 of these records may have included credit card or other financial information regarding bill payment.

name: BNY Mellon Shareowner Services
description: May 2008. A back-up tape, containing over 12 million customers records were lost.

name: Countrywide Financial Corp
description: Aug 2008. A former employee was sentenced Tuesday to eight months in prison & ordered to repay $1.2 million after pleading guilty to downloading millions of borrower files on thumb drives & selling the information to other loan officers

name: UK Home Office
description: Aug 2008. PA Consulting lost an unencrypted memory stick containing details of high risk, prolific and other offenders.

name: Countrywide Financial Corp
description: Aug 2008. Rene Rebollo, a former senior financial analyst at Countrywide, stole & sold customer data over a 2 year period.

name: RBS Worldpay
description: Dec 2008. The hack primarily effected U.S. prepaid and the gift card issuing business of RBS Worldpay. Actual fraud has been committed on approximately 100 cards.  Certain personal information of approximately 1.5 million cardholders and other individuals may have been affected and, of this group, Social Security numbers of 1.1 million people may have been accessed.

name: Auction.co.kr
description: Feb 2008. South Koreaâs largest online shopping site was attacked by a Chinese hacker who made off with the user information on 18 million members & a large amount of financial data.

name: GS Caltex
description: Sep 2008. Two multimedia discs containing the names, social security numbers, addresses, cell phone numbers, email addresses and workplaces of Korean customers sorted by age were stolen. They were found by an office worker in a backstreetâs trash pile in Seoul. Experts say a GS Caltex employee likely stole the information for personal purposes given there were no signs of hacking.

name: AT&T
description:
Jun 2008. A laptop was stolen from a car containing unencrypted Social
Security numbers and bonus/salary info of AT&T employees.

name: Stanford University
description: Jun 2008. Tens of thousands of past and current Stanford University employees had personal information - including their dates of birth, Social Security numbers and home addresses - stored on the hard drive of a stolen university laptop.

name: University of Utah Hospitals & Clinics
description: Jun 2008. The data tapes were stolen by petty thieves from an employee's car. According to police reports the thieves tried - and failed - to view the tapes using a VHS player.

name: Chile Ministry Of Education
description: May 2008. A computer hacker in Chile published confidential records belonging to six million people to illustrate the weakness of their security.

name: Jefferson County
description: Nov 2008. "Jefferson County Clerk Jennifer Maghan said she unveiled a new online search tool that enabled residents and business professionals to access nearly 1.6 million documents that are stored in her office via their home computers"

name: Texas Lottery
description: Nov 2008. Data on more than 89,000 lottery winners (including names, Social Security numbers, addresses and prize amounts )were taken from the agency without permission by a former computer analyst who copied the password-free data. The employee added he wanted the information "for possible future reference as a programmer at other state agencies."

name: Starbucks
description: Nov 2008. A laptop was stolen that contained private information on 97,000 employees, including names, addresses and Social Security numbers. Employees tried to sue Starbucks in California winning their case in the appeals court before losing in the higher federal court as they were unable to prove any cognizable harm or injury.

name: UK Ministry of Defence
description: Oct 2008. Hard drive containing very sensitive details of Armed Forces personnel - passport & national insurance numbers, bank details etc - went missing. Loss was revealed during National Identity Fraud Prevention Week.

name: T-Mobile, Deutsche Telecom
description: Oct 2008. Thieves got their hands on a storage device with the data, which included the names, addresses, cell phone numbers, and some birth dates and e-mail addresses for high-profile German citizens. The company said the records did not contain bank details, credit card numbers, or call data.

name: Norwegian Tax Authorities
description:
Sep 2008. "Tax authorities said they had accidentally sent CD-ROMs filled with the 2006 tax returns of nearly four million people living in Norway, a country of 
just 4.6 million inhabitants, to the editorial staff at national 
newspapers, radios and television stations."

name: Service Personnel and Veterans Agency (UK)
description: Sep 2008. Stolen USBs containing personal information about private lives of staff.

name: Monster.com
description: Aug 2007. A trojan virus stole log-ins that were used to harvest user names, e-mail addresses, home addresses and phone numbers. Soon after phishing e-mails encouraged users to download a Monster Job Seeker Tool, which was in fact a program that encrypted files in their computer and left a ransom note demanding money for their decryption.

name: Driving Standards Agency
description: Dec 2007. Hard disk with details of candidates for the driving theory test was lost in a premises in Iowa by subcontractors. Only names, addresses and phone numbers.

name: Fidelity National Information Services
description: Jul 2007. Employee sold customer information to a data broker, including names, addresses, birth dates, bank account and credit card information.

name: City and Hackney Teaching Primary Care Trust
description: Dec 2007. Heavily encrypted disks containing details of children are lost by couriers.

name: Gap Inc
description: Sep 2007. Stolen laptop which contained social security numbers, data on people who applied for positions at Gap stores, including Banana Republic and Old Navy, between July 2006 and June 2007.

name: Dai Nippon Printing
description: Mar 2007. A former contractor of Dai Nippon Printing Company in Tokyo, Japan stole 8.6 million records containing the personal data of customers of 43 of the company's clients.

name: TK / TJ Maxx
description: Mar 2007. Hackers hacked a Minnesota store wifi network and stole data from credit and debit cards of shoppers at off-price retailers TJX, owners of nearly 2,500 stores, including T.J. Maxx and Marshalls. This case is believed to be the largest such breach of consumer information.

name: JP Morgan Chase
description: May 2007. The personal information of approximately 2.6 million current and former holders of a Chase-Circuit City credit card had been mistakenly identified as trash and thrown out in garbage bags outside five branch offices in New York.

name: UK Revenue & Customs
description: Nov 2007. A set of discs containing confidential details of 25 million child benefit recipients was lost.

name: TD Ameritrade
description: Sep 2007. TD Ameritrade settled a class action lawsuit to compensate as many as 6.3 million TD Ameritrade customers whose data was stolen by hackers costing the Nebraska online brokerage firm less than $2 per victim.

name: AOL
description: Aug 2006. Derp. AOL voluntarily released search data for roughly 20 million web queries from 658,000 anonymized users of the service. No one is quite sure why.

name: US Dept of Vet Affairs
description: Jul 2006. The Veterans Affairs Department agreed to pay $20 million to settle a class action lawsuit over the loss of a laptop. The department originally took three weeks to report the theft. The laptop was recovered with the data apparently intact a month after it was reported stolen. But it is impossible to say with absolute certainty that the data was not accessed and copied.

name: Automatic Data Processing
description: Jul 2006. Automatic Data Processing, one of the world's largest payroll service companies, confirmed that it was swindled by a data thief looking for information on hundreds of thousands of American investors.

name: KDDI
description: Jun 2006. Press report: "Tokyo police have arrested two men for trying to extort nearly US$90,000 from KDDI Corp. The pair allegedly threatened to disclose the existence of storage media containing personal data belonging to four million KDDI customers prior to a shareholder meeting; however, KDDI alerted the police as soon as they were contacted by the blackmailers; the police monitored communications between KDDI and the pair for several weeks. "

name: Hewlett Packard
description: Mar 2006. Laptop lost/stolen containing employee data: names, addresses, Social Security numbers, dates of birth and other employment-related information.

name: Ameritrade Inc.
description: Apr 2005. Computer backup tape containing personal information was lost.

name: Citigroup
description: Jun 2005. Blame the messenger! A box of computer tapes containing information on 3.9 million customers was lost by United Parcel Service (UPS) while in transit to a credit reporting agency.

name: Cardsystems Solutions Inc.
description: Jun 2005. CardSystems was fingered by MasterCard after it spotted fraud on credit card accounts and found a common thread, tracing it back to CardSystems.  An unauthorized entity put a specific code into CardSystems' network, enabling the person or group to gain access to the data. It's not clear how many of the 40 million accounts were actually stolen.

name: AOL
description: Jun 2004. A former America Online software engineer stole 92 million screen names and e-mail addresses and sold them to spammers who sent out up to 7 billion unsolicited e-mails.
